learningOutcomes.fi: Opiskelija tutustuu arkkitehtuurin tekemisen erilaisiin lähestymistapoihin ja ajatteluun, muodostaa niistä omaa näkemystään ja esittää sen kirjoittamalla esseenä.
learningOutcomes.sv: Den studerande bekantar sig med olika närmandesätt och tankeprocesser inom skapandet av arkitektur, bildar egna uppfattningar om dem och framför sina tankar i en essä.
learningOutcomes.en: The student learns about the different approaches to architecture and architectural thinking, forms their own viewpoint on these, and then presents this viewpoint as a written essay.

learningOutcomes.fi: Students will gain a solid grounding in key topics in contemporary philosophy of technology with a special focus on aesthetics and ethics of new and emerging technologies. Critical thinking is learned through gaining knowledge of central concepts and narratives concerning technological developments. The studentswill become more fluent in using different concepts and analysing discourses around various types of technologies. The students will gain confidence in discussing the role and of different technologies and tools and in understanding the role of the human agency in technological processes. Throughout the course, there is a special emphasis on creative and artistic processes.
learningOutcomes.sv: Students will gain a solid grounding in key topics in contemporary philosophy of technology with a special focus on aesthetics and ethics of new and emerging technologies. Critical thinking is learned through gaining knowledge of central concepts and narratives concerning technological developments. The studentswill become more fluent in using different concepts and analysing discourses around various types of technologies. The students will gain confidence in discussing the role and of different technologies and tools and in understanding the role of the human agency in technological processes. Throughout the course, there is a special emphasis on creative and artistic processes.
learningOutcomes.en: Students will gain a solid grounding in key topics in contemporary philosophy of technology with a special focus on aesthetics and ethics of new and emerging technologies. Critical thinking is learned through gaining knowledge of central concepts and narratives concerning technological developments. The studentswill become more fluent in using different concepts and analysing discourses around various types of technologies. The students will gain confidence in discussing the role and of different technologies and tools and in understanding the role of the human agency in technological processes. Throughout the course, there is a special emphasis on creative and artistic processes.

content.fi: The course concentrates on contemporary trends in philosophy of technology with a focus on aesthetics, sustainability, and art. We will discuss how technology-related theories and concepts affect and help to analyse different types of creative practices. Besides contemporary philosophy of technology and aesthetics, other central content areas of the course include ethics, pragmatism, philosophy of the city, and environmental philosophy. The theoretical contents are discussed with a broad range of case examples which contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of the human-world and human-nonhuman relations and how technology contributes to them.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Students with an interest in entrepreneurship but not yet an own business idea or business.
prerequisites.sv: Recommended prerequisites: Students with an interest in entrepreneurship but not yet an own business idea or business.
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: Students with an interest in entrepreneurship but not yet an own business idea or business.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Students will learn:
 
-to understand business opportunities and practices of their own arts and design fields
-to gain an overview of basic professional and business practices in their respective fields
-to create a personal entrepreneurship career assessment
-to gain basic business literacy and skills including user research, marketing etc
-to apply this knowledge to a specific arts and design field or market
-to give a professional presentation on their ideas
-to understand how to build sustainable work methods

-to understand how to build sustainable work methods

content.fi:
Entrepreneurial practices, what is entrepreneurship, planning, negotiating, calculating and optimizing.
Students will work individually and in small groups to analyze the business practices of their fields and define characteristics of an ideal art entrepreneur. What needs to be done to keep customers happy, bank balance on the plus side and mental and physical health in check. Exercises include role model interviews, customer interviews and reflection. Essentially, they go through the business model canvas. They will also practice negotiating skills and make financial calculations. The sessions include guest lecturers from different areas of creative industry and discussions about dilemmas related to the relationship between art and entrepreneurship.
Final submission will be a presentation of the entrepreneurial landscape of a specific creative field

learningOutcomes.fi:
Students will learn:
-to develop skills directly related to the next steps they need to take with their business
-to apply entrepreneurial skills to a real-life project
-to understand customer needs and wants
-to understand how to build sustainable work methods

-to understand how to build sustainable work methods

content.fi:
Students will start/continue their own project and try to make it economically self-sustaining.
Course starts with a personal interview with each student to understand the student's situation. After the interview, the students prepare – together with the course teachers - a personal “workout” plan. At the end of the course, students should be able to either continue to an incubator, an innovation program or run their business. Using the entrepreneurial theory of Effectuation, the students explore the ENT landscape of their art or design fields. This includes understanding the market, vocabulary and mindsets, using their own research and practitioner experiences from real life.

learningOutcomes.fi: - After completing this course you can articulate your individual needs and understand the needs of others with whom you work in artistic collaborations - You will gain tools for building trust in the people you work with and an awareness of the different roles involved in working together. - You will develop skills to generate and achieve collaborative outcomes.
learningOutcomes.sv:
- After completing this course you can articulate your individual needs and understand the needs of others with whom you work in artistic collaborations
- You will gain tools for building trust in the people you work with and an awareness of the different roles involved in working together.
- You will develop skills to generate and achieve collaborative outcomes.
learningOutcomes.en:
- After completing this course you can articulate your individual needs and understand the needs of others with whom you work in artistic collaborations
- You will gain tools for building trust in the people you work with and an awareness of the different roles involved in working together.
- You will develop skills to generate and achieve collaborative outcomes.

content.fi: What is the beauty and challenge of working with others? How do you navigate and embrace the sometimes messy processes of artistic collaboration? During this course you will work on a playful, collaborative project in groups. By the end of the course, you will have tools and skills to achieve goals in and through collaborative artistic processes.

assesmentMethods.fi: An attendance of 80% is required to pass the course. Each group assesses itself at the end of the course. Course grading is based on attendance, group assessment and the learning diary.

additionalInformation.fi:
Teaching Language: English Teaching Period: 2024-2025 Autumn I  2025-2026 Autumn II Registration: Prioritization order for admission is based on the prioritization criteria established by Aalto ARTS:
https//www.aalto.fi/en/services/registering-to-courses-and-the-order-of-priority-at-aalto-arts
After the registration has closed, SISU conducts a raffle to allocate all the seats while considering the possible prioritisation order stated above. If there are more registrants than available seats, ten (10) students from the remaining applicants are drawn and placed on a waiting list in numerical order. On the first day of the course, these students may check for available seats in case of no-shows. Any available seats are then filled in numerical order.
All applicants will receive an email containing details about the registration status, once the registration period has closed.
Minimum amount of participants is 8 students, maximum 30.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Willingness to work outdoors.
prerequisites.sv: Recommended prerequisites: Willingness to work outdoors.
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: Willingness to work outdoors.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the students are able:

- to observe spaces, routines, pressure systems, communities and structures in the city, especially in their close surroundings and neighbourhoods. - use experimental and artistic tools such as experimental drawing techniques, installation, spatial intervention and writing to express the observations. - communicate with new tools and give feedback to others and share with the group insights also on subjects strange to them.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course the students are able:- to observe spaces, routines, pressure systems, communities and structures in the city, especially in their close surroundings and neighbourhoods.
- use experimental and artistic tools such as experimental drawing techniques, installation, spatial intervention and writing to express the observations.
- communicate with new tools and give feedback to others and share with the group insights also on subjects strange to them.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the students are able:- to observe spaces, routines, pressure systems, communities and structures in the city, especially in their close surroundings and neighbourhoods.
- use experimental and artistic tools such as experimental drawing techniques, installation, spatial intervention and writing to express the observations.
- communicate with new tools and give feedback to others and share with the group insights also on subjects strange to them.

content.fi:
During the course the student will explore structures, communities, pressure systems and networks in their surroundings and neighbourhoods. The course will concentrate on city related structures that are for example technological, transitional, social, literal, invisible, or imaginative. Their effects on our bodies, routines and our daily life will be discussed and conceptualized in our artistic practice.
The emphasis of the course is on studying structures, pressure systems and networks of the city from a moving or mingling point of view. We approach the city with artistic practices like experimental dawning, interventions, performative art, writing, experimental moving image etc. We work with the environments and communities in and around us. The course is hence held mostly in the city (outdoors) and on the move.

We approach the city with artistic practices like experimental dawning, interventions, performative art, writing, experimental moving image etc. We work with the environments and communities in and around us. The course is hence held mostly in the city (outdoors) and on the move.

learningOutcomes.fi:
• You will be able to plan, schedule, and create an artwork for a site-specific online exhibition.
  • You will gain an understanding of how documentation images are changing the ways in which we look at, participate in, and generate art.
  • You have developed skills in planning, documenting, and post-processing exhibition documentation images.
learningOutcomes.sv:
• You will be able to plan, schedule, and create an artwork for a site-specific online exhibition.
  • You will gain an understanding of how documentation images are changing the ways in which we look at, participate in, and generate art.
  • You have developed skills in planning, documenting, and post-processing exhibition documentation images.
learningOutcomes.en:
• You will be able to plan, schedule, and create an artwork for a site-specific online exhibition.
  • You will gain an understanding of how documentation images are changing the ways in which we look at, participate in, and generate art.
  • You have developed skills in planning, documenting, and post-processing exhibition documentation images.

content.fi: This course explores the possibilities of exhibition making in the age of digital images, utilizing so-called off-site location(s) to imagine, create, display, and document artworks. While experience of independent artistic practice is required, extensive background in exhibition making is not necessary. By the end of the course, each student will have created an online PDF exhibition using their own and their classmates' documentation images of the artworks made during the course.

assesmentMethods.fi: The course requires 80% attendance at group and individual tutoring sessions, the production of an artwork for a specific site, the documentation of this and the production of a PDF using images from all artworks made during the course, and learning diary entries. Assessment emphasises individual processes rather than a set objective.

name.fi: The Colourful Past: A Historical Exploration of Colours, Natural Dyes and Dyeing, Luento-opetus
name.sv: The Colourful Past: A Historical Exploration of Colours, Natural Dyes and Dyeing, Föreläsning
name.en: The Colourful Past: A Historical Exploration of Colours, Natural Dyes and Dyeing, Lecture

workload.fi:
The course consists of lectures, seminar discussions, and material experiments.
During the course, we will work with images, texts, printed primary sources, and textile and dye materials. The visual, material, and written evidence is examined in a broad interdisciplinary context, including making, in order to provide students with a methodological introduction of how to interpret and obtain new knowledge of the history of colours and dyes from a range of sources.
24h contact teaching / 57h independent working
workload.sv:
The course consists of lectures, seminar discussions, and material experiments.
During the course, we will work with images, texts, printed primary sources, and textile and dye materials. The visual, material, and written evidence is examined in a broad interdisciplinary context, including making, in order to provide students with a methodological introduction of how to interpret and obtain new knowledge of the history of colours and dyes from a range of sources.
24h contact teaching / 57h independent working

The course consists of lectures, seminar discussions, and material experiments.

The visual, material, and written evidence is examined in a broad interdisciplinary context, including making, in order to provide students with a methodological introduction of how to interpret and obtain new knowledge of the history of colours and dyes from a range of sources.
24h contact teaching / 57h independent working

prerequisites.fi: Compulsory prerequisites: Students admitted to the course must independently complete the ARTS Textile workshop chemical safety course during the first week of the course.
prerequisites.sv: Compulsory prerequisites: Students admitted to the course must independently complete the ARTS Textile workshop chemical safety course during the first week of the course.
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: Students admitted to the course must independently complete the ARTS Textile workshop chemical safety course during the first week of the course.

learningOutcomes.fi: The principal aim of this material culture and dress history course is to study some of the key historical developments of colour in textiles and fashion in the early modern period. After the succesful completion of the course, the student will understand some of the tways in which colours were used in dress and fashion; have knoweldge of  the complex economic, social and cultural meanings associated with colours and natural dyes; and obtain new knowledge about materials and making, colour innovation, and the trade of dye stuffs in Europe in the first global age.
learningOutcomes.sv: The principal aim of this material culture and dress history course is to study some of the key historical developments of colour in textiles and fashion in the early modern period. After the succesful completion of the course, the student will understand some of the tways in which colours were used in dress and fashion; have knoweldge of  the complex economic, social and cultural meanings associated with colours and natural dyes; and obtain new knowledge about materials and making, colour innovation, and the trade of dye stuffs in Europe in the first global age.
learningOutcomes.en: The principal aim of this material culture and dress history course is to study some of the key historical developments of colour in textiles and fashion in the early modern period. After the succesful completion of the course, the student will understand some of the tways in which colours were used in dress and fashion; have knoweldge of  the complex economic, social and cultural meanings associated with colours and natural dyes; and obtain new knowledge about materials and making, colour innovation, and the trade of dye stuffs in Europe in the first global age.

content.fi:
Colour was an essential element in early modern European fashion. The importance of colour was based not only on its aesthetic or symbolic significance, but it was also linked to the fact that producing some colours and achieving perfect tones was an expensive and complicated procedure. In addition to the costly process of obtaining dyes, transferring the raw material into colour required skill and specialized knowledge about how the dyestuffs reacted with different chemicals and fabrics.
This course introduces students to the history of colours, natural dyes and dye practices in connection with early modern dress and fashion. It focuses on the making and meaning of colours in dress during a period (c. 1500-1750) of significant interest in material and aesthetic experimentation and intensified global trade in textiles and dye stuffs. The specific seminar topics include the use of colour in fashion; the meanings and value of colours in dress and their connections with wealth and power; dyers, dye stuffs and dye practices; the availability of colour recipes; and the processes of making of colours. The course involves both lectures as well as material hands-on experimentation with colours and natural dyes in a lab setting.

If there are more registrants than available seats, ten (10) students from the remaining applicants are drawn and placed on a waiting list in numerical order. On the first day of the course, these students may check for available seats in case of no-shows. Any available seats are then filled in numerical order.
All applicants will receive an email containing details about the registration status, once the registration period has closed.
Minimum amount of participants is 8 students, maximum 12.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Game Design Fundamentals AXM-E5010 (but can also be done in reverse order)
prerequisites.sv: Recommended prerequisites: Game Design Fundamentals AXM-E5010 (but can also be done in reverse order)
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: Game Design Fundamentals AXM-E5010 (but can also be done in reverse order)

learningOutcomes.fi: 1 Explain key questions and subthemes of game design
learningOutcomes.sv: 1 Explain key questions and subthemes of game design
learningOutcomes.en: 1 Explain key questions and subthemes of game design

content.fi: The game design course consists of a series of lectures of visiting lecturers from the games industry. It opens perspectives on key  questions of game design and development through the varied experiences of the visitors, ranging from indie to AAA game projects. Different subthemes inside game design are covered, like prototyping, level design, narrative design, UX design and mobile game design.
content.sv: The game design course consists of a series of lectures of visiting lecturers from the games industry. It opens perspectives on key  questions of game design and development through the varied experiences of the visitors, ranging from indie to AAA game projects. Different subthemes inside game design are covered, like prototyping, level design, narrative design, UX design and mobile game design.
content.en: The game design course consists of a series of lectures of visiting lecturers from the games industry. It opens perspectives on key  questions of game design and development through the varied experiences of the visitors, ranging from indie to AAA game projects. Different subthemes inside game design are covered, like prototyping, level design, narrative design, UX design and mobile game design.

assesmentMethods.en: To pass, participation in teaching, completed assignments. Minimum 80% attendance. The course is assessed based on written lecture reflections.

learningOutcomes.fi:
1 Describe and apply the iterative game design process
2 Create and analyse board game rule systems on a prototype level
learningOutcomes.sv:
1 Describe and apply the iterative game design process
2 Create and analyse board game rule systems on a prototype level
learningOutcomes.en:
1 Describe and apply the iterative game design process
2 Create and analyse board game rule systems on a prototype level

content.fi: The course consists of a one-week workshop. It covers the bases of theory and methods of game design and includes practical design exercises. In the workshop, the nature of games and game design is discussed, as well as meaningful decisions and balance of chance and skill. Board game design exercises bring a hands-on aspect to the course.
content.sv: The course consists of a one-week workshop. It covers the bases of theory and methods of game design and includes practical design exercises. In the workshop, the nature of games and game design is discussed, as well as meaningful decisions and balance of chance and skill. Board game design exercises bring a hands-on aspect to the course.
content.en: The course consists of a one-week workshop. It covers the bases of theory and methods of game design and includes practical design exercises. In the workshop, the nature of games and game design is discussed, as well as meaningful decisions and balance of chance and skill. Board game design exercises bring a hands-on aspect to the course.

learningOutcomes.fi: The course qualifies the student to work independently in watercolour woodblock printmaking and opens up opportunities to expand personal artistic expression.
learningOutcomes.sv: The course qualifies the student to work independently in watercolour woodblock printmaking and opens up opportunities to expand personal artistic expression.
learningOutcomes.en: The course qualifies the student to work independently in watercolour woodblock printmaking and opens up opportunities to expand personal artistic expression.

content.fi: Japanese woodblock printmaking is a non-toxic method of relief printmaking. All pigments used are water-based and most materials and tools come directly from Japan. During the course you will learn how to use the carving tools properly and how to register a multi-colour print perfectly. In addition to the basic working methods, you will learn various printing techniques of traditional mokuhanga and you will have the opportunity to examine real old ukiyo-e prints from the teacher's collection.
content.sv: Japanese woodblock printmaking is a non-toxic method of relief printmaking. All pigments used are water-based and most materials and tools come directly from Japan. During the course you will learn how to use the carving tools properly and how to register a multi-colour print perfectly. In addition to the basic working methods, you will learn various printing techniques of traditional mokuhanga and you will have the opportunity to examine real old ukiyo-e prints from the teacher's collection.
content.en: Japanese woodblock printmaking is a non-toxic method of relief printmaking. All pigments used are water-based and most materials and tools come directly from Japan. During the course you will learn how to use the carving tools properly and how to register a multi-colour print perfectly. In addition to the basic working methods, you will learn various printing techniques of traditional mokuhanga and you will have the opportunity to examine real old ukiyo-e prints from the teacher's collection.

additionalInformation.fi:
Teaching Language: English Teaching Period: 2024-2025 Spring III - IV  2025-2026 Spring III - IV Registration: Prioritization order for admission is based on the prioritization criteria established by Aalto ARTS:
https//www.aalto.fi/en/services/registering-to-courses-and-the-order-of-priority-at-aalto-arts
After the registration has closed, SISU conducts a raffle to allocate all the seats while considering the possible prioritisation order stated above. If there are more registrants than available seats, ten (10) students from the remaining applicants are drawn and placed on a waiting list in numerical order. On the first day of the course, these students may check for available seats in case of no-shows. Any available seats are then filled in numerical order.
All applicants will receive an email containing details about the registration status, once the registration period has closed.
Minimum amount of participants is 8 students, maximum 12.

learningOutcomes.fi:
1 Reflect on games from new perspectives (depends on what topics students choose to dive into)
2 Discuss the (Finnish) game industry
learningOutcomes.sv: 1 Reflect on games from new perspectives (depends on what topics students choose to dive into)2 Discuss the (Finnish) game industry
learningOutcomes.en: 1 Reflect on games from new perspectives (depends on what topics students choose to dive into)2 Discuss the (Finnish) game industry

content.fi:
The game seminar is a course where the students have a chance to look at games from different points of view, listening to presentations and discussing them, doing exercises, watching relevant video material and visiting game industry events and companies. It is also supporting the students other game projects by providing an arena where people can test and comment on each other's work, and also play other games to increase their knowledge of games and game related phenomena.
This course code exists so that the game seminar course can be taken another time, because the content changes every year. Register to this if you want to take the game seminar course for a second time.
content.sv:

It is also supporting the students other game projects by providing an arena where people can test and comment on each other's work, and also play other games to increase their knowledge of games and game related phenomena.
This course code exists so that the game seminar course can be taken another time, because the content changes every year. Register to this if you want to take the game seminar course for a second time.
content.en:
The game seminar is a course where the students have a chance to look at games from different points of view, listening to presentations and discussing them, doing exercises, watching relevant video material and visiting game industry events and companies. It is also supporting the students other game projects by providing an arena where people can test and comment on each other's work, and also play other games to increase their knowledge of games and game related phenomena.
This course code exists so that the game seminar course can be taken another time, because the content changes every year. Register to this if you want to take the game seminar course for a second time.

learningOutcomes.fi: The student will be familiar with basic programming techniques used to create computer generated visual images and animations.
learningOutcomes.sv: The student will be familiar with basic programming techniques used to create computer generated visual images and animations.
learningOutcomes.en: The student will be familiar with basic programming techniques used to create computer generated visual images and animations.

content.fi: The emphasis of this course is to introduce students to programming languages and techniques that can be used to create screen-based visuals using computational techniques, live data sources, etc. The main programming environments used will be Processing and HTML5. Passing the course requires 80 percent attendance and completion of the exercises.
content.sv: The emphasis of this course is to introduce students to programming languages and techniques that can be used to create screen-based visuals using computational techniques, live data sources, etc. The main programming environments used will be Processing and HTML5. Passing the course requires 80 percent attendance and completion of the exercises.
content.en: The emphasis of this course is to introduce students to programming languages and techniques that can be used to create screen-based visuals using computational techniques, live data sources, etc. The main programming environments used will be Processing and HTML5. Passing the course requires 80 percent attendance and completion of the exercises.

assesmentMethods.fi: Individual and small group discussion and critique. Active participation in classwork. Successful completion of own project. Passing the course requires 80 percent attendance and completion of the exercises.
assesmentMethods.sv: Individual and small group discussion and critique. Active participation in classwork. Successful completion of own project. Passing the course requires 80 percent attendance and completion of the exercises.
assesmentMethods.en: Individual and small group discussion and critique. Active participation in classwork. Successful completion of own project. Passing the course requires 80 percent attendance and completion of the exercises.

additionalInformation.fi:
Teaching Language: English Teaching Period: 2024-2025 Spring IV  2025-2026 Spring IV Registration: Prioritization order for admission is based on the prioritization criteria established by Aalto ARTS:
https//www.aalto.fi/en/services/registering-to-courses-and-the-order-of-priority-at-aalto-arts
After the registration has closed, SISU conducts a raffle to allocate all the seats while considering the possible prioritisation order stated above. If there are more registrants than available seats, ten (10) students from the remaining applicants are drawn and placed on a waiting list in numerical order. On the first day of the course, these students may check for available seats in case of no-shows. Any available seats are then filled in numerical order.
All applicants will receive an email containing details about the registration status, once the registration period has closed.
Minimum amount of participants is 8 students, maximum 15

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: ARTS-A0115 Taiteen nykykäytännöt: Studio A and ARTS-A0116 Taiteen nykykäytännöt Studio B or ARTS-A0124 Johdatus taiteelliseen työskentelyyn or ARTS-A0119 Contemporary Practices: Studio A and ARTS-A0120 Contemporary Practice: Studio B or ARTS-A0125 Introduction to artistic practices or equivalent previous BA- or MA-level art studies.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course:
  • You recognize and know how to utilize the visual properties of colour in your artistic work.
  • You dare to look for new ways to experiment with colours, materials, and techniques in painting.
  • You can plan and implement an artwork or a series of works independently.
  • You will find connections between your artistic interests and the operating environment of the visual arts to support your personal development.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course:
  • You recognize and know how to utilize the visual properties of colour in your artistic work.
  • You dare to look for new ways to experiment with colours, materials, and techniques in painting.
  • You can plan and implement an artwork or a series of works independently.
  • You will find connections between your artistic interests and the operating environment of the visual arts to support your personal development.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course:
  • You recognize and know how to utilize the visual properties of colour in your artistic work.
  • You dare to look for new ways to experiment with colours, materials, and techniques in painting.
  • You can plan and implement an artwork or a series of works independently.
  • You will find connections between your artistic interests and the operating environment of the visual arts to support your personal development.

content.fi: The course focuses on painting and experimenting with colours, medium and materials. The concepts and visual properties of colour are explored in relation to one's own artistic work. Use and meanings of colours are also examined in art and in the work of contemporary artists. Based on one’s own idea and plan, a painting project will be carried out. A personal learning diary is kept to document experiments and course work and to reflect on what has been learned.

assesmentMethods.fi:
• Attendance in contact teaching. Completion of the assigned course work by the time set by the teacher.
  • Active participation in class work, critiques, and discussions.
  • Development in artistic work and experimentation with colour, medium and materials.
  • The quality of reflection and presentation of one's own creative process. Conceptual considerations related to art and colour, as well as linking artistic interests to the broader context of art.

additionalInformation.fi:
Teaching Language: English Teaching Period: 2024-2025 Autumn II  2025-2026 Autumn II Registration: Minimum amount of participants is 8 students. Maximum amount of participants is 20 students.
Prioritization order for admission is based on the prioritization criteria established by Aalto ARTS https//www.aalto.fi/en/services/registering-to-courses-and-the-order-of-priority-at-aalto-arts
Students with following recommended prerecuisites fullfilled are prioritized:
ARTS-A0115 Taiteen nykykäytännöt: Studio A and ARTS-A0116 Taiteen nykykäytännöt Studio B, or ARTS-A0124 Johdatus taiteelliseen työskentelyyn or ARTS-A0119 Contemporary Practices: Studio A and ARTS-A0120 Contemporary Practice: Studio B or ARTS-A0125 Introduction to artistic practices, or equivalent previous BA- or MA-level art studies.
After the registration has closed, SISU conducts a raffle to allocate all the seats while considering the prioritization order stated above. Accepted students must show up on the first course day or inform the teacher in advance of absence to confirm their place in the course.If there are more registrants than available seats, 10 students from the remaining are drawn and placed on a waiting list in numerical order. These students are informed by e-mail. On the first day of the course, they may check for available seats. The available seats are then filled in numerical order.
